slides.title: Welcome
slides.body:
**

Welcome to Rhythms and You (RAY)

**

RAY is based on a tested psychological treatment that helps people understand and manage the symptoms of bipolar disorder. We have had a lot experience helping others like you improve their mood by learning about how routines affect mood.

In RAY, you will learn about your body clock, routines, and mood. You will also learn to communicate better with important people in your life and your doctor.

Many people also take medication to help them manage their moods and bipolar disorder. Talk to your doctor about whether medications are right for you.

Here's what people are saying about RAY:

"I learned about the importance of getting up at the same time every day. It's hard but it helps." ---Hiroko, age 24

"I've noticed that my mood is much worse when I skip meals. I used to forget to eat dinner when I worked late, but now I am really careful about my routines. It helps me feel better." ---Jason, age 38

"When my kids are on vacation, my schedules gets crazy. That is when I get depressed. RAY helped me learn about the importance of routines for the whole family." --Kelly, age 41

slides.title: Meet Your Body Clock!
slides.body: Everyone has a body clock!

slides.title: What Does Your Body Clock Do?
slides.body:
Your body clock controls the timing of many important activities in your body

  1. Sleep
  2. Energy
  3. Appetite
  4. Blood Pressure
  5. Digestion
  6. Concentration

slides.title: The Rhythm of Life
slides.body:
**

Although you may not be aware of it, your body clock controls many of your life rhythms. These are called your Circadian Rhythms.

Read more about Circadian Rhythms here: NIH Circadian Rhythms Fact Sheet

slides.title: What Are Circadian Rhythms?
slides.body:
Circadian rhythms are body processes controlled by a collection of biologic pacemakers located throughout the body that run on an approximate 24 hour cycle.

  • The main pacemaker (biologic clock) is located in the brain, but pacemakers can be found in almost every organ including skin and stomach
  • Circadian rhythms are controlled by internal factors (the body clock) and external factors (environmental cues)
  • Virtually all living organisms (including plants!) have circadian rhythms
  • Circadian rhythms help plants and animals live harmoniously with their environment

Click here to learn more about the biology of Circadian Rhythms

slides.title: When Circadian Rhythms Miss a Beat
slides.body:
**

Like all timekeepers, body clocks sometimes get off track and have to be reset.

**

A good example is jet lag.

  • When you travel to a new time zone, your body is on a different schedule from the new environment, because your body clock stays for some time on the circadian rhythm you developed in your previous time zone.
  • The longer you stay in the new time zone, the more your body clock aligns with the external clock.
  • The process of alignment is driven by environmental cues, especially light and darkness, which tell your body clock whether it is day or night.
  • Other cues that help re-set your body clock: when you eat and when you are active/inactive
  • Jet lag occurs when your body clock is out of sync with cues from a new time zone.

Symptoms of being out of sync with your body clock include:
1. Fatigue
2. Sleepiness
3. Poor appetite
4. Difficulty with concentration
5. Irritability
6. Change in bowel habits

slides.title: Body Clock and Mood Disorders
slides.body:
What does your body clock have to do with your mood disorder?

When you have a mood disorder

  1. Your body clock is much more sensitive to shifts in schedules, time zones, and routines
  2. It is harder for your body clock to stay regular
  3. When your body clock gets off track, it is harder for it to get back on track
  4. Not having a regular routine make your moods worse

slides.title: Resetting the Clock
slides.body:
You can re-set your body clock by giving it some hints. Here are some ideas to get started. We will talk a lot more about this in Rhythms And You (RAY)

  1. The body clock is very sensitive to light and dark.
    HINT: Making sure that you expose your eyes to light in the morning and stay in darkness at night helps your body clock to "keep time."

  2. Daily routines remind your body clock about timing.
    HINT: Sticking to regular routines helps your body clock stay on track.

  3. Your stomach and intestines have sensors that helps to keep your body clock on track.
    HINT: Regular mealtimes are important for your body clock.

  4. Social activities also help keep your clock on track.
    HINT: Regular interactions with friends and family provide important cues for your clock.

slides.title: Rhythm Checks
slides.body:
**

Learn to monitor your daily rhythms with the Social Rhythm Metric (SRM).

**

Fill out the SRM this week so that you can learn more about your body clock and its rhythms.

slides.title: Is Your Body Clock Regular?
slides.body:
How regular is your body clock? Below are some questions that will help you think about regularity of your body clock. We will pay a lot of attention to regular rhythms in RAY.

  1. Do you go to bed at the same time every night?
  2. Do you get up at the same time every day?
  3. Do you have dinner every night?
  4. Do you exercise every day?
  5. Do you see other people at the same time every day?

If you answered "no" to one or more of these questions, you can work on improving the regularity of your rhythms which will, in turn, help your mood.

Let's get started!

slides.title: Introduction to Remembering a Well Period
slides.body:
Can you remember a "Well Period"? This would be a time when you

  • Functioned well in your personal and work life (though not so "well" as to be characterized as manic)
  • Made rational decisions
  • Felt neither consistently down or nor consistently up/irritable

The goal of the next exercise it to remember your routines during a well period

  • Did you have have regular routines during your well period?
  • Was there a connection between your routines and mood?
  • Which came first...routines or mood?
  • How similar (or different) are your current routines from those during the well period ?

The next exercise will ask you to reflect on these questions.

slides.title: Introducing the Social Rhythm Metric
slides.body:
Now that you've had a chance to think about your routines during a well period, let's focus on your current routines.

The Social Rhythm Metric (SRM)

  • Helps you keep track of your daily routines and rhythms
  • Takes less than a minute to complete
  • Should be completed every day
  • Shows you the relationship between your rhythms and your mood
  • Allows you to set rhythm goals for yourself

This week, you will start by filling out the SRM. You will be asked to record the time that you do each of the following activities:

  • Time you get out of Bed
  • First Contact with Another Person
  • Time that you start your usual daily activity
  • Dinner Time
  • Bed Time

Next week we will check to see how that went for you.

slides.title: SRM FAQs
slides.body:
** Here are some tips about questions that commonly arise when completing the SRM**

Time Out of Bed

  • Record the time that your feet hit the ground in the morning (your body clock has sensors that can tell you are vertical)
  • If you get up to use the bathroom and then go back to bed briefly, it doesn't count
  • If you are out of bed for at least 30 minutes, count that as your Time Out of Bed (even if you go back to bed later for a nap)
  • If you are awake but lying in bed, don't record "Out of Bed" until your feet are on the floor for at least 30 minutes.

First Contact with Another Person

  • This refers to your first reciprocal contact with another person. How you define "reciprocal" is up to you.
  • "Reciprocal" typically means that the other person responds to you in real time. Texts don't usually count because there is often a delay before the other person responds. However, if you get a quick response from a text, you may decide it counts.
  • Facebook probably doesn't count, but Facebook Messenger might, if the person responds immediately.
  • If you pass your roommate in the bathroom and he or she says "hi," that counts.
  • If you order a latte from a barrista at a coffee shop, that counts.
  • If your cat jumps on your head and wakes you up, that does not count. It has to be a person.

Time that you start your usual daily activity

  • Usual daily activity can be anything: a job, housework, classes, volunteer work. The idea is to pick something that you do multiple times per week.
  • There may be days when you do not have a daily activity (for instance, if you work Monday through Friday but do not work on the weekend).
  • If you have different kinds of activities that you do across the week but each of them gets you out of the house, you can use different activities each day (for instance, on Mondays and Wednesday, you play golf, on Tuesdays and Thursdays you volunteer in the local school, on Fridays you have a book club, and on Sunday you go to church).

Dinner Time

  • Record the time that you eat (rather than prepare) dinner. Your body clock has sensors in the intestinal track that is affected by the time that you eat your meals.
  • If you do not eat dinner on a specific day, it will be recorded as missing. This is important information that you will examine in subsequent weeks.

Bed Time

  • Record the time that you turn out the lights for the night with the intent to go to sleep.
  • If you get into bed at 10:30 pm and read for half an hour before turning off the lights at 11 pm, you would record 11 pm as your bed time.
  • If you are up and down multiple times during the night, record the time that you first tried to go to sleep for at least 30 minutes.
  • If you fall asleep on the couch for an hour after dinner, get up and the go to bed at 1 am for the rest of the night, record 1 am as your bed time. The time on the couch would be considered a nap.

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
It makes a lot of sense that you might resist the idea of sticking to a routine.

Most of us would rather just do what we feel like doing in any given moment.

But the research definitely shows that the more you stick to a routine, the more stable your mood will be.

Even small changes in this direction are helpful.

slides.title: Blues: What are Moods and Mood Disorders?
slides.body:
I am in bad mood!

Every one has "moods" which are defined by temporary or passing feelings or emotional states.

A bad mood may cause someone to have a bad day but rarely interferes with relationships or jobs or life satisfaction.

I have a mood disorder!

Some people have "mood disorders" which are a group of illnesses (including major depressive disorder and bipolar disorder) in which problems with mood are a primary feature.

Mood disorders often cause problems with relationships and jobs.

Examples of mood disorders include depression and bipolar disorder.

To learn more about depression, visit this website: NIH Information About Depression

slides.title: What is Bipolar Disorder?
slides.body:
**

Bipolar Disorder

**

  • Previously called manic-depressive illness
  • A brain disorder that causes changes in mood, energy, and activity
  • Often runs in families
  • Affects the body clock
  • Characterized by mood swings ("mania" or "hypomania" alternating with "depression")
  • Usually starts when a person is in their teens or early adulthood
  • Treated with medications and psychotherapy

Read more about bipolar disorder here NIH Information on Bipolar Disorder

Or watch this video

slides.title: What are the Symptoms of a Depressive Episode?
slides.body:
Symptoms of depression include:

  • At least two weeks of feeling sad or down most of the day, nearly every day
  • Loss of interest in activities, including food and sex
  • Feeling tired or slowed down
  • Having trouble concentrating, focusing, or making decisions
  • Being restless or irritable
  • Eating too much or too little
  • Sleeping too much or too little
  • Thinking of death or suicide or attempting suicide

Click here to watch a video about depression

slides.title: What are the Symptoms of a Manic Episode?
slides.body:
Mania can be very severe, sometimes requiring hospitalization. It often causes problems with jobs and relationships

Mania is diagnosed when someone experiences at least a one week period of several of these symptoms:

  • Feeling "too" happy or being very irritable
  • Talking very fast
  • Thoughts jumping from topic to topic
  • Being easily distracted
  • Sleeping very little and yet not feeling tired
  • Having lots of energy
  • Starting lots of new projects or getting involved in many more activities than usual
  • Having an unrealistic view of one's abilities
  • Acting impulsively
  • Engaging in high-risk behaviors like spending a lot of money or being sexually promiscuous
  • Unrealistic thoughts like hearing voices that do not exist or feeling frightened for no reason

slides.title: What is Hypomania?
slides.body:
"Hypo" means "below" or "beneath"

"Hypomania" refers to an episode of mania that is "below" mania in its intensity. Hypomania does not usually result in hospitalization or cause problems with jobs. It may, however, have an impact on your relationships.

If you experience hypomania, you may have at least 4 consecutive days when you :

  • Feel better than usual
  • Have more energy than usual
  • Have more interest in sex
  • Need less sleep
  • Speak more quickly
  • Eat less
  • Do more activities

Hypomania can feel really good for a while, but it doesn't last.

slides.title: Suicide and Bipolar Disorder
slides.body:
Suicide is a common consequence of bipolar disorder

Facts about suicide and bipolar disorder

  • About 20% of people with bipolar disorder die by suicide.
  • 25-50% of people with bipolar disorder attempt suicide at least once.
  • Getting treatment helps: people are less likely to kill themselves if they get treatment for their illness.

Signs of suicide risk include

  • Wishing for death or thinking that they would be better off dead
  • Thinking about or looking for ways to kill themselves
  • Saying or feeling that they are a burden to others
  • Giving away prized possessions
  • Saying goodbye to close family members or friends
  • Writing a suicide note

If you or someone you know is showing signs of suicide risk, call 911 or go to the nearest emergency room.

Or call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline
1-800-273-TALK

slides.title: What Kind of Bipolar Disorder Do I Have?
slides.body:
Bipolar Disorder is many things.

  • "Bipolar Disorder" and "Manic Depression" are the same thing ("Manic Depression" is the old name)
  • Bipolar I Disorder is alternating manic and (usually) depressive episodes.
  • Bipolar II Disorder is alternating hypomanic and depressive episodes.
  • Bipolar Disorder, unspecified type, is alternating mild hypomanic and depressive episodes

slides.title: Depression and Bipolar Disorder: Same or Different?
slides.body:
Can I have both depression and bipolar disorder?

If you have bipolar disorder, your depression is part of your bipolar disorder. You can't have a diagnosis of both depressive disorder and bipolar disorder.

In bipolar disorder, depressions occur more frequently than mania or hypomania.

Once you experience a single episode of mania or hypomania, your diagnosis changes from depressive disorder to bipolar disorder.

Getting a correct diagnosis is important because doctors often recommend different treatments for depressive disorders and bipolar disorder.

slides.title: Maybe It's Not Bipolar Disorder
slides.body:
Making a diagnosis of bipolar disorder (I, II, or unspecified) is sometimes difficult because other disorders can be confused with bipolar disorder and sometimes co-occur with bipolar disorder. Below are some mental health disorders that are sometimes confused with--and sometimes co-occur with--bipolar disorder.

  • Borderline Personality Disorder (for more information, visit NIMH Information on Borderline Personality Disorder)

  • Anxiety Disorders (for more information, visit NIMH information on Anxiety Disorders)

  • Drug Abuse (for more information about the mental health effects of drug abuse, visit NIDA's information on mental health effects of drug use)

slides.title: Learning to Rate Your Moods
slides.body:
In the next exercise, you will learn to rate your mood.

The Mood Thermometer proceeds from +5 to -5
+5=the most manic you have ever felt
-5=the most depressed you have ever felt

"Normal" moods range from +1 to -1
+1 = a little bit upbeat (how you feel after getting some good news)
-1 = a little bit down (how you feel when you are having a bad day)

0= very level mood

Moods in the range of +2 to -2 suggest that early signs of depression or mania are present but not yet out of control. Here are some examples of what these ratings mean
+2 = really up, starting to feel like nothing can get me down
-2 = low interest, pulling away from people and not wanting to talk much

Each person will experience different symptoms at each level on the Mood Thermometer.

Complete your personal Mood Thermometer to identify your own symptoms at each mood level.

slides.title: Q & A about the  Mood Thermometer
slides.body:
Q: If I was upset about something that happened at work, would I rate my mood as -1?

A: I think it depends on how upset you were. If it was just a blip, I think a -1 would be right. If you spent the whole day crying and feeling like you wanted to crawl into bed, you might go for a -2. If you had suicidal thoughts, maybe it would be -3.

Q: When I get manic, I get more irritable than happy. How would I rate that?

A: That’s very common. The plus side of the scale is used for an overly happy or an overly irritated mood. Most people at +4 or a +5 have some degree of irritability.The plus sign may be misleading. These aren’t necessarily positive states, although they may feel that way some of the time.

Q: So zero is good?

A: With this scale, a zero is a normal mood.

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
The position of the sun in the morning (low on the horizon) tells your body clock that the day has started.

Go for a walk outdoors in the morning, even when it is cold or cloudy! A quick stroll will give you enough sun exposure to signal your body clock that it's time to start the day.

No time to take a walk? Just open the curtains and windows or simply turn on your brightest lights. Light in the morning is good for your body clock!

lesson.title: Finding the Beat: Daily Anchors for Rhythms and Mood

slides.title: What is a Zeitgeber?
slides.body:
Zeitgeber= "Timekeeper"

Zeitgebers help keep your Circadian Clock on track.

The rising and setting of the sun is the most powerful and regular Zeitgeber in our environment.

slides.title: What is a Social Zeitgeber?
slides.body:
A Social Zeitgeber --or anchor--is a social factor that keeps your schedule and your Circadian Clock on track. Here are some examples:

  1. Tim's dog always wakes me him at 6:30 a.m. to let him out. If Tim doesn’t get up, the dog makes a mess in the house. Tim's dog is a social rhythm anchor because he helps get Tim up at the same time every morning.

  2. Janelle's mother is a social anchor for her. Even though they live far apart, she calls her mother every day around dinner time. If she forgets to call her, her mother gives Janelle a really hard time. Even though Janelle sometimes resents having to call her mother, she almost never forgets that phone call.

Can you think of some social anchors in your life?

slides.title: Examples of Social Anchors
slides.body:
Common social anchors include:

  1. Dropping children off at school
  2. Eating a meal with a family member
  3. Starting work or school or a volunteer activity
  4. Taking your medications
  5. Taking bath or shower
  6. Exercise
  7. Feeding a pet
  8. Calling a friend/relative
  9. Helping children with homework
  10. Doing housework

Do any of them apply to your life?

What activities or social connections help anchor your routines?

slides.title: Using Social Anchors to Keep the Beat
slides.body:
Social anchors help your body clock keep its rhythm.

  1. Think about activities in your life that happen at the same time every day. These activities help to keep your clock regular.
  2. Think about activities that happen at different times most days of the week. Changes in routines may confuse your body's clock.

What can you do to help your body clock stay regular?

  • Develop more regular routines in your daily life. This will help to "train" your body clock
  • RAY will help you set goals to establish more regular routines

slides.title: Using the SRM to Set Goals
slides.body:
The Social Rhythm Metric (SRM) helps you track 5 daily activities. Setting SRM goals will help your body clock become more regular.

Look at your SRM for the past week. Pick one activity that you think would benefit from being a little bit more regular. Set one (and only one!) goal for this week. Here are examples of SRM goals that you may choose:

  1. I will try to get up at the same time every day this week
    Tip: don't try to get up earlier than usual; just try to get up at the same time every day.
  2. I will try to start my daily activity at the same time every day this week.
    Tip: Find something to do on Saturdays and Sundays too.
  3. I will eat dinner at the same time every day.
    Tip: Try to find someone who will meet you for meals. It will increase the chance that you will do it. Social contact may also help your mood.
  4. I will go to bed at the same time every night
    Tip: Your getting up time sets your sleep time, so you may want to focus on your wake time before working on your bedtime.

slides.title: Setting Target Times for SRMs
slides.body:
This week we will add target times for the SRM

Based on your past week's SRMs, the RAY program has generated average times that you are doing each of the 5 SRM activities. This is now considered your "target time" for each activity.

You can change the target time by adjusting it on your SRM.

We recommend that you do not change your target time by more than 30 minutes per week for any given activity. If you make abrupt changes, you will confuse you body clock and experience jet lag-like symptoms.

slides.title: Barriers to Achieving SRM Goals
slides.body:
Don't feel discouraged if you set an SRM goal and have trouble meeting it. Achieving regular routines is harder than it sounds. Lots of people have trouble meeting their goals at first.

RAY will give you specific suggestions to help you meet your goals. But, here are some general thoughts to get you started:

  • Pick small, manageable goals: Aim to make small changes, such as shifting your schedule by 15 minute increments.
  • Break goals into smaller parts: If you want to make a big change, break it into smaller components, and then work on one part at a time.
  • Depression makes it harder: If you are depressed, give yourself a break. Low energy and low motivation are symptoms of depression. It will take a bit longer to get where you want to go, but you will get there.

Don't get discouraged. RAY will help.

slides.title: Rhythms and Mood
slides.body:
As you complete your SRMs this week pay attention to the following:

  1. How close are you to your target time?
  2. Is your mood affected when you are closer to/farther away from your target time?
  3. Is there a relationship between your mood ratings and the overall level of regularity on your daily activities?
  4. When you make changes to rhythms, does it have an impact on your mood?

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
Bright, artificial light in the evening confuses your body clock, making it think you are outside in daylight.

As bedtime approaches, try to avoid bright lights.

If you wake up in the middle of the night, don't turn the overhead light on. Use a small, dim nightlight instead so you don't "wake up" your body clock by mistake.

slides.title: Physical Health and Bipolar Disorder
slides.body:
If you have bipolar disorder, you may be at higher risk for some of the following health problems.

  1. Diabetes
  2. Heart disease
  3. Thyroid problems
  4. Migraine headaches
  5. High blood pressure
  6. Obesity

It is very important that you see your medical doctor for regular check ups!

slides.title: Rhythms and Physical Health
slides.body:
Circadian rhythms affect physical health too

Irregular daily rhythms can increase the levels of "bad" inflammatory factors in your bloodstream, contributing to your risk for

  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Migraine headaches

Poor sleep, a common part of dysregulated rhythms, is associated with

  • Heart problems
  • Decreased productivity at work and home
  • Poor concentration
  • Obesity

Regular rhythms are good for your mental and physical health!

slides.title: Exercise and Me
slides.body:
When you are depressed, it can be really hard to exercise because depression causes

  • low energy
  • increased sleep
  • low motivation
  • worse concentration

And yet, regular exercise can help reset your body clock and improve your mood.

Here are some tips to help you get moving, even when you are depressed:

  • Set small, manageable exercise goals to start. A short walk may be a reasonable goal for you.
  • Do not try to do too much
  • Find a friend who will exercise with you to improve your motivation
  • Find something you enjoy doing (rather than something that feels like a chore)
  • Don't get discouraged; if you have trouble getting started or slip up, just set a smaller goal and build up more slowly
  • Try using a fitness app
  • Try using a personal health monitor to measure number of steps you take each day. Increase your steps by 50 each day to reach your goal.

For some excellent suggestions about getting started with a healthy fitness program , visit this NHS website

Make sure you check with your doctor first to make sure that any new exercise program is safe for you!

slides.title: Talking to Your Doctor About Bipolar Disorder
slides.body:
You may wish to discuss your mental health with your doctor at your next visit. Here are some topics that you may wish to raise:

  • Diagnosis
  • Bipolar Disorder and physical health
  • Bipolar Disorder and sexual health
  • Medications for Bipolar Disorder
  • Other health care providers (psychologists, psychiatrists) who can help with Bipolar Disorder

It can be hard to start a conversation with your doctor about these topics.

Get your GAME on to work more effectively with your doctor

GET READY
ASK QUESTIONS
MAIN POINTS
EMPHASIZE YOUR WISHES

The next exercise will help you get your GAME on with your doctor.

slides.title: Supranormal Rhythms
slides.body:
May people tell us at the beginning of RAY that going to bed at the same time every night and getting up at the same time every morning is crazy!

  • Jim said, "No one I know gets up early on the weekend. Everyone likes to sleep in on the weekends after a hard work week."
  • Kaitlyn said, "No one in college has a regular schedule. I can't possibly get up at the same time every day. It depends on my classes."
  • Arjun said, "I hate living on a schedule. I like spontaneity. That's how I roll."

We are asking you do something a little weird...to develop supranormal rhythms. Supranormal means "above" normal or "more than" normal

  • If you have diabetes, you have to be extra careful about your sugar intake—more careful about eating sugary foods than a person without diabetes—in order to stay healthy.
  • The same thing is true for schedules and bipolar disorder: if you have bipolar disorder, you have to keep a very regular schedule—more regular than someone who does not have bipolar disorder.
  • This may not seem fair, and maybe it isn’t fair, but it is also not fair that a person with diabetes has to be very careful about his diet.
  • This is something that you can do for yourself to help improve your mood and help keep you well. Keeping a regular schedule is a way that you can exert control over your illness.

After developing supranormal routines with RAY, this what we were told:

  • Jim said, "It is still annoying to set my alarm for 8 am on Saturday and Sunday, but Monday mornings are now so much easier for me. I am also much less angry with my kids and have more energy overall."
  • Kaitlyn said, "I have convinced my roommates to eat breakfast with me every morning, even if we don't have an early class. I make coffee for all four of us and it is really kind of fun. My concentration during the day is much better, and I am no longer sleeping through my classes. It is definitely worth it."
  • Arjun said, "I still like spontaneity, but I reward myself for having dinner every night at 7 pm by cooking some awesome spicy meals with my girlfriend. We have gotten much more creative with our recipes since we are planning around my routines. She is really into helping me because when I stay on track with my schedule, I am less out of control and nicer to her. I can also concentrate better on my music in the evening if I have eaten something substantial. And, of course, it helps me go to bed on time."

slides.title: More About SRM Goal Setting
slides.body:
Last week you were asked to set an SRM Goal. Let's evaluate your progress on your SRM goals.

  • Did you meet your SRM goal?
  • If not, why not?
  • Was there a connection between achieving or not achieving your SRM goal and your mood this week?

The next RAY exercise

  • Will be helpful for you if you had trouble reaching your goal.
  • Will help you set your next goal if you were successful this week in reaching your first goal.

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
As we discussed, disordered circadian rhythms play a role in medical illnesses such as:

  • obesity
  • cancer
  • migraine headaches

The modern world is confusing to our circadian rhythms because

  • Artificial light at night makes our bodies think it is daytime long after sunset
  • The constant availability of food makes it unnecessary for us to eat at specific times of day

Some scientists think that our bodies' efforts to overcome the confusing effects of artificial light and modern schedules may be major contributors to the global obesity epidemic.

Read more about it here.

Regular rhythms may help not only your mood but also your body.

lesson.title: Rhythms and Sleep: Strategies for Better Sleep

slides.title: Why Do We Sleep?
slides.body:
**

Sleep Facts

**

We spend one third of our lives asleep.
Some parts of the brain are more active at while we sleep than when we are awake.
Sleep enhances memory and creativity.

slides.title: What Happens When We Don't Get Enough Sleep?
slides.body:
Many of us are sleep deprived, especially

  • Teenagers
  • Shift-workers
  • Older adults
  • Most of us! In the 1950's, we got 8 hours of sleep; today, the average adult gets only 6.5 hours of sleep

When you are sleep-deprived, you are at an increased risk for:
- Driving accidents
- Poor judgment at work
- Poor memory
- Increased impulsiveness
- Weight gain
- Cravings for stimulants (caffeine, nicotine) and carbohydrates

slides.title: Sleep is Important
slides.body:
Getting good sleep is one the most important things you can do for your health!

Better sleep will help your

  • Mood
  • Body Clock
  • Brain
  • Memory
  • Physical health

slides.title: How Does My Brain Control Sleep?
slides.body:
Sleep is Regulated By Two Processes

The Sleep or "S" Process:

  • Your brain measures the amount of time you have been awake.
  • This "sleep juice" builds up during the day.
  • The longer you have been awake, the more "sleep juice" builds up.
  • Sleep drive, or sleep juice, decreases quickly while you are asleep.

The Circadian or "C" Process:

  • Your body clock run on roughly a 24 hour cycle, controlled by chemicals in the brain.
  • Your body clock increases your sleep drive in the middle of the night and decreases it in the middle of the day.
  • The times that it’s hardest to stay awake are from about 3 - 6 a.m. (if you’ve been awake all night).
  • If you stay awake longer, you notice a “second wind” of alertness kicking in later in the morning, at 9 a.m. to noon.
  • Your body clock makes sure that you’re less sleepy during the day than at night.

slides.title: The S and C Processes Work Together to Ensure Optimal Sleep
slides.body:
Two Forces that Guide Your Sleep Work Together

At the end of the day, your “sleep juice” is high because of how long you’ve been awake; that helps you fall asleep.

Later in the night, your body clock’s sleep drive reaches a peak, helping you to stay asleep.

These graph shows you what "good" sleep patterns look like. Notice the following:

  • The sleep drive is increasing over the period of wakefulness ("W").
  • The Circadian drive to sleep is lowest during the period of wakefulness ("W").
  • As sleep starts (blue shading), both the sleep drive are high and the Circadian drive to sleep are high.
  • Around 5 am, both the S and C drives start to drop, preparing the body for wakefulness.
  • The S and C drives are in sync.

[insert graph from BBTI hand out here]

slides.title: What Happens When The S and C Processes Don't Work Together?
slides.body:
Sometimes the S and C process do not align and sleep goes wrong.

Here are some examples of how sleep can go wrong.

[insert graphs from BBTI handout]

slides.title: 4 "Easy" Steps to Improving Sleep
slides.body:
1. Reduce your time in bed
  2. Don't go to bed unless you're sleepy
  3. Don't stay in bed unless you're asleep
  4. Get up at the same time every day

Let's think more about each of these sleep tips!

slides.title: Reduce Your Time in Bed
slides.body:
If you are experiencing trouble sleeping at night (more than 30 minutes of wakefulness during the night), consider reducing your time in bed:

  • If your brain is able to get 6 hours of actual sleep at night, but you spend 11 hours in bed, then you’re guaranteed to have 5 hours of wakefulness in bed.
  • That can lead to lots of frustration, which can actually make your sleep worse still.
  • “Sleep juice” is increased by increasing amounts of wakefulness during the day. Cutting down your time in bed increases the time you’re awake, which of course increases that same “sleep juice.”
  • When we say to decrease time in bed, we are not really aiming to decrease the amount of sleep you get in bed, just the amount of wakefulness you have in bed.
  • Remember that it is not that unusual for it to take up to a half hour to fall asleep, so don't worry if you are awake for 30 minutes before falling asleep

slides.title: Strategies for Reducing Time in Bed
slides.body:
Your goal is to reduce Time in Bed to Total Sleep Time + 30 minutes.

Pick your target Out-of-Bed time.
Work backward from there to decide your target Bedtime.
Keep these ideas in mind:

  • Always make changes slowly, altering your schedule by no more than 30 minutes per day.
  • Always spend at least 7 hours in bed, even if that is more than Total Sleep + 30 minutes.

EXAMPLE: Bob is in bed from 2 am to noon (10 hours) but only sleeping for 6 1/2 hours per night. Bob's goal is to spend 7 hours in bed (6 1/2 hours plus 30 minutes). He would like to go to get up at 8 am but knows that he has to make the change gradually

  • Bob moves his Out-of-Bed time back by 30 minutes on Day 1: he goes to bed at the same time (2 am) but gets up at 11:30 am instead of noon.
  • On Day 2, Bob goes to bed at 2 am and gets up at 11 am.
  • On Day 3, Bob goes to bed at 2 am and gets up at 10:30 am.
  • On Day 4, Bob goes to bed at 2 am and gets up at 10 am.
  • On Day 5, Bob goes to bed at 2 am and gets up at 9:30 am.
  • On Day 6, Bob goes to bed at 2 am and gets up at 9 am. At this point, he has hit his goal of 7 hours in bed. But, he has not yet met his goal of getting up at 8 am.
  • Next, Bob moves his Bedtime and Out-of-Bed time back by 30 minutes (1:30 am Bedtime and 8:30 am Out-of-Bed time).
  • On Day 7, Bob goes to bed at 1:30 am and gets up at 8:30 am.
  • On Day 8, Bob reaches his goal: he goes to bed at 1 am and gets up at 8 am.

slides.title: Don't Go To Bed Unless You're Sleepy
slides.body:
Sleepy is when your eyes are drooping, your head is nodding, you can’t pay attention to the conversation around you because you are slipping into a twilight state.

  • If you’re not sleepy at your “bedtime,” you shouldn’t go to bed yet.
  • Let yourself stay up a little longer, and only go to bed when you’re actually feeling that you could fall asleep.
  • This step also helps to increase your “sleep juice,” because it’s just another way of increasing the amount of time you’re awake.

Tiredness or fatigue is a different state that may or may not indicate readiness for sleep.

  • When you are tired or fatigued, you may have low energy, your muscles may be sore, or you may not be interested in doing anything.
  • This may be part of your depression or it may indicate that you have been working hard all day.
  • It is not necessarily an indication that it is time for bed.

Don't spend more than 30 minutes trying to fall asleep.

  • After 30 minutes, get out of bed and go to a pre-selected dark spot where you can engage in other QUIET activities (such as listening to music) until you become sleepy
  • Going to bed when not sleepy can lead to vicious cycle of frustration that sends your brain the wrong message
  • Don’t rely on your medications to make you sleepy ; your body clock and the S process will help you fall asleep if you let them

slides.title: Don't Stay In Bed Unless You Are Asleep
slides.body:
If you are awake for more than 30 minutes in the middle of the night, get out of bed

  • Helps to train your brain: Bed = sleep
  • Reduces frustration

What to do if you can’t sleep and have to get up in the night

  • Keep lights as dim as possible—no overhead lights
  • Do something distracting and relaxing, not too engaging or stimulating
  • STAY OFF THE COMPUTER/SMARTPHONE! (too bright, too engaging)
  • Watching TV is okay if from a distance and the program is not too stimulating
  • If you read, be careful that the lamp is small and not pointed at your eyes

WARNING: If you think that you may be getting manic (see information on symptoms of mania), quiet rest in bed, even while awake, may be better than getting out of bed where risk of becoming more active is high

slides.title: Get Up at the Same Time Every Day
slides.body:
Getting up at the same time every morning helps set the body clock

  • Wake-up time (and morning light) is the most important cue for the biological clock
  • Try to get some exposure to light as soon as you wake up: take a walk or sit on your porch
  • If you’ve slept poorly, getting up at the same time helps you sleep better the next night
  • When you get up at the same time every day, your body clock has an easier time "knowing" when it is time to tell your body to go to sleep If you get up at different times, the clock gets "confused" and your ability to fall asleep will suffer
  • You can "force" yourself to get up in the morning, but you cannot "force" yourself to fall asleep; you have more control over your Out-of-Bed time than Bedtime
  • Try not to nap even if you are tired so that the "sleep juice" can build up for the next night

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
Teenagers' body clocks are shifted

Most teenagers's body clocks are set to go to sleep later and get up later.

Yet, many high schools start very early in the morning.

As a result, many teenagers' body clocks are still "sleeping" during the first few school periods, resulting in worse school performance and cranky adolescents.

School districts that have shifted to later start times for higher grades have found that high school students have better test scores and improved concentration.

The moral of this story : you can't fight your body clock!

Read more about this issue in a statement from the American Academy of Pediatrics or in this online article in The Atlantic

lesson.title: Even Better Sleep: Mood, Sleep, and Rhythms

slides.title: Rules For Better Sleep
slides.body:
#How to Get Ready For Bed

###A short Animation Will Explain some of the key ways you can get ready to get great sleep.

slides.title: More Ways To Get A Good Nights Rest
slides.body:
1. Reduce or eliminate caffeinated beverages after 5 pm.
  2. Try not to smoke when you are having trouble sleeping – nicotine is a stimulant.
  3. Daily exercise can help deepen sleep. Do not exercise too close to bedtime; plan to finish at least four hours before you turn in.
  4. Exposure to bright light prior to bedtime may interfere with sleep. When possible, eliminate exposure to bright artificial light (overhead lights, computer screens) in the 2 hours before bedtime. Television viewing is okay if done at a safe distance from the screen (6 feet or more).

slides.title: What Else Can I Do To Sleep Better?
slides.body:
1. Make your bedroom comfortable and free of disturbing noise and light. Carpeting, insulated curtains, and closing the door can help.
  2. Keep room temperature moderate. A room that is too warm or too cold can disturb sleep.
  3. Only use the bedroom for sleep and sexual activity. Do not read, eat, or watch TV in bed. This helps train your brain to see the bedroom as a place to sleep.
  4. Develop a bedtime routine to prepare your brain and body for sleep. Take a warm bath or drink a cup of warm milk while listening to quiet music.

slides.title: What About Naps?
slides.body:
Naps use up some of your "sleep juice" so you are less sleepy as night time approaches.

If you are having trouble falling asleep at night, naps are a bad idea.

If you absolutely must nap, follow these guidelines:

  • Restrict naps to no longer than 30 minutes
  • Set an alarm (on your phone, on your watch) so you don't oversleep
  • Don't nap after 5 pm

slides.title: What About Taking Medications To Help Me Sleep?
slides.body:
Medications can be prescribed in the short term to help with insomnia. However, there are probably more problems than benefits associated with using sleeping medications to address insomnia, especially if used for more than a few days.

Pro's of prescription sleep medication

  • They can help to break patterns of poor sleep and provide some relief for those who cannot seem to get much sleep.
  • Use of sleep medications can supplement behavioral strategies (attention to daily rhythms) to address insomnia.
  • It may be easier to "pop a pill" than to make changes to routines and rhythms.

Con's of prescription sleep medication

  • Many prescription sleep medications lead to dependency--i.e., more sleep problems than when you started; rebound insomnia from medication when you try to stop taking the pills.
  • All sleeping pills cause trouble with memory and concentration both immediately after taking the pill and the next day.
  • Long term use can cause tolerance and lead to need for higher doses of drugs.
  • Medication rarely provides lasting relief from insomnia.
  • The long term safety of sleeping pills is not known.
  • Sleeping pills cannot over-ride the body clock when it is very dysregulated.

** Check with your doctor to see what's right for you. Always check with your doctor before stopping a prescribed medication.**

slides.title: The Truth About Alcohol and Sleep
slides.body:
Question: Is drinking alcohol to help you sleep a good idea or bad idea?

Answer: Drinking alcohol to help you sleep is a bad idea because:

  • When you drink alcohol close to bedtime, you miss out on the deep, restorative stage of sleep so you will not feel refreshed in the morning.
  • Alcohol is a diuretic, which means that you will wake up many times during the night to use the bathroom.
  • Drinking makes it more likely that you will snore and sleep fitfully because it relaxes the muscles in your body, including those in your throat and nose.
  • Alcohol is a central nervous system depressant--which means it can make your depression worse.

slides.title: Strategies for Getting Out of Bed
slides.body: (animation)_MEC entered when noticed it was missing

slides.title: More Strategies For Getting Out of Bed
slides.body:
ON WAKING UP

• Place encouraging/coping thoughts on a notecard on bedside table; read immediately
• Place pros and cons list of getting out of bed on bedside table; read immediately
• Listen to tape you made reminding yourself of reasons to get up
• Place water on bedside table; splash on face or drink
• Place something with strong smell on table; inhale (e.g. cinnamon)
• Throw off the covers immediately • Put feet on the floor immediately
• Get up and take a shower

HAVE A REASON TO GET UP EVERY DAY

• Set appointment or make plan for doing something in morning (e.g. go to work, go to volunteer job, go to exercise)
• Get a pet

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
The world can be divided into "larks" and "owls."

Larks are people whose body clocks run a little bit ahead of environmental clocks. They are biologically predisposed to get up early and go to bed early.

Owls are people whose body clocks run a little bit behind the environmental clock. They are biologically predisposed to get up late and go to bed late.

This predisposition is also called a chronotype.

Individuals with bipolar disorder commonly have an owl chronotype.

Most people are better off if they can find a job or lifestyle that fits with their chronotype. It is hard to fight against your body clock!

lesson.title: Skipped Beats: Finding the Beat after Rhythm Disruptions

slides.title: The Sensitive Body Clock
slides.body:
A sensitive or "weak" body clock easily loses its rhythm

  • Doesn't have a strong beat
  • Shifts quickly from one rhythm to another

In evolutionary terms, a "weak" clock allows animals to adapt quickly to new environments

  • Migratory birds with "weak" rhythms can adapt more easily to new light/dark cycles when flying across multiple time zones

  • Arctic animals with "weak" rhythms can feed whenever food is available without being tied to a specific time of day

However, a sensitive human body clock has trouble maintaining rhythms, especially in an environment with confusing external cues such as lights blazing at night-time and constantly available food. The sensitive clock is

  • Easily dysregulated when the environment changes
  • Unable to re-assert its own rhythm when the beat is lost
  • Associated with mood instability

If you have bipolar disorder, you probably have a sensitive body clock.

slides.title: What is a Zeitstorer?
slides.body:
Zeitstorer means "time taker" or "time disturber."

Zeitstorers are external factors that disrupt the body clock.

Examples of Zeitstorers are:

  • Switching from Daylight Savings Time to Standard Time or visa versa
  • Travel across time zones
  • Staying up all night because of a stomach virus
  • Natural disasters (floods, hurricanes, storms)
  • Going into labor

slides.title: What is a Social Zeitstorer?
slides.body:
Social Zeitstorers are social demands or factors that disrupt your routines and body clock.

Examples of social Zeitstorers include:

  • Business trips
  • Unexpected house guests
  • Rotating shift work
  • Exams/heavy work demands
  • Caregiving for sick family members
  • Having a newborn baby
  • New jobs
  • Retirement

slides.title: Managing Rhythm Disrupting Events
slides.body:
We all experience rhythm-disrupting events in our lives. How can we manage them to minimize the impact on our body clocks?

Plan ahead!

  • If you know that an event is in your future, take steps to minimize disruptions to your routines by asking friends or family to stick to your schedule or help you out.
  • New mothers, for instance, may ask someone else to take night feedings rather than risk disrupting their own sleep.
  • Employees may discuss travel schedules with their boss to limit trips across time zones or number of trips per month.
  • Students may work with their disability office to stagger their exams so that they can get enough sleep between major assessments.

If your body clock gets out of rhythm, try to get back on track as soon as possible.

  • If you spend the night in an emergency room, you may need to take a brief nap the next day, but try to go to bed at your usual time and get up the following day at the usual time so your body clock can re-set itself.
  • Remember that exposure to light in the morning can help your clock reset itself, so ask your unexpected house guests to take a walk with you in the morning.
  • If you lose your job or go on vacation, put activities in place that keep you busy during times that your would have been busy on your old schedule.

slides.title: More Planning for Rhythm Disruption
slides.body:
Here are more tips to manage rhythm disruptions:

  • Especially when you are in the midst of a rhythm disrupting event (travel across time zones, exam period), be sure to eat meals at regular times.
  • When your life feels chaotic, try to get some exercise every day (even if it is for a short time) to help keep your body clock on track.
  • Regular rhythms are good for the whole family! If you have a major change in your family rhythms (vacation, holidays, visitors), get everyone involved in a regular routine. Put up a big calendar or dry erase board where you can write down the times for meals and scheduled events. If you can get everyone in your household to follow a schedule, it will help you stay on track--and it will help them too.
  • If you are trying to reset your clock after an episode of dysregulation, be sure to get out of bed and stay upright for a while (walk around the kitchen while you drink your coffee). Your body clock can "sense" when your are upright, and that helps it know that it is daytime.
  • If you have been spending too much time on the computer at night to complete work, consider installing a program on your computer that automatically dims the intensity of the light emitted by the screen as the evening progresses. It will help cue your brain that sleep time is approaching.

slides.title: Psychological Distress and Rhythm Disruption
slides.body:
Events often cause both psychological distress and rhythm disruption.

We are used to thinking about the impact of psychological distress. Of course, it is very important to address psychological distress, often by talking to a trusted friend, confidant, or professional.

However, you can also work on reducing the the effect of rhythm disruption on your mood as part of the healing process. Consider the following scenario.

Juanita lost her husband David of 55 years to cancer. Juanita had devoted her adult life to raising her children (now adults themselves) and, more recently, to caring for her sick husband. After David's death, Juanita felt terrible. She missed her husband and felt very alone.

Juanita found comfort in talking to her pastor and her children about her grief. But she struggled at home by herself. Juanita may benefit from paying attention to her social rhythms, previously set by caring for David. She now needs to find new anchors for her daily activities. Suggestions for Juanita might include:

  • Join a grief group to help increase social contacts.
  • Set up at least one activity a day to get you out of the house: meet someone for coffee, volunteer at church, go to mass, visit your grandchildren.
  • Make meals for yourself every evening, even if you don't really feel like eating. Then eat at least a little bit.
  • Try to stay awake until at least 9:30 pm to stick to a regular bedtime like you did when David was alive. If you cannot find anything to do after dinner, try calling your grandchildren, listening to a book on tape, signing up for Bible study at church, or invite a friend for dessert.

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
Did you know that plants have body clocks too?

  • Circadian rhythms were first discovered in plants
  • Some plants open and close their leaves in response to the light/dark cycle to optimize sun exposure and moisture collection
  • This process is controlled by genes in the circadian clocks of plants

slides.title: People and Mood
slides.body:
Relationships affect your mood!

  • When things are going well in your relationships, you usually feel better.
  • When there are problems in relationships, you usually feel worse.

The opposite is also true:

  • When your mood is bad, your relationships suffer.
  • When your mood is good, you are better able to manage your relationships.

slides.title: Social Changes, Rhythms, and Mood
slides.body:
Our lives change constantly, and we move from one social role to another as our lives evolve.

Social role changes can have a big impact on your mood by altering your relationships and your social rhythms.

Have you experienced any of these social role changes in the last year?

  • Single to married or partnered
  • In the army to civilian life
  • Employed to unemployed
  • Childless to being a parent
  • Student to a professional
  • Financially o.k. to not enough money
  • Healthy to sick

If you experienced any of these changes, it probably affected:

  • Your mood
  • Your relationships
  • Your daily rhythms

In the next exercise, we will explore your life changes in the past year and the impact of those changes on your rhythms and mood.

slides.title: Managing Social Changes
slides.body:
Social changes are disruptive to your moods and rhythms. Here are some strategies to help you manage social changes.

Keep your rhythms the same as you go through the change. Even though your schedule may change when you move from working to being unemployed, try to stick to a schedule that is similar to one that you followed while you were working.

When you have a new baby, although your sleep schedule may change, you can stay on the same meal schedule and work in regular exercise.

Don't over-value the past

We often miss the past. As a result, we idealize things that may not have been perfect. When you find yourself missing the past, try to evaluate both the pros and cons of the old social role.

  • Martin was angry and upset that he was no longer in charge of his division at work. He felt like he had been demoted by the new boss. This seemed to affect his mood. When he sat down to list the pros and cons being Division Head, he started to remember all of the cons. Although he was still angry at his boss, he realized it was a relief to no longer have to deal with disrgruntled salesmen, division budgets, and hiring freezes. He felt better reminding himself that it wasn't always perfect in the past.

Don't under-value the present

When we are stressed about our current circumstances. we often have trouble seeing the positive aspects of the present. When you are worried about current challenges. try to evaluate both the pro's and con's of the new social role.

  • Jaden was really upset about breaking up with Tony. She was angry about the way things ended and really unhappy about being single again. She had really hoped that things would have worked out with him. She was depressed, feeling despondent about being single. One of her girlfriends, however, urged her to write down the pros and cons of being single again. At first, she couldn't think if any pros. But then she started to remember that Tony was pretty demanding, leaving her little time to hang out with her friends and even less time to exercise or work on her novel. Although she was still sad about the break up, she admitted that there was an upside.

slides.title: The Break-Up
slides.body:
Meghan and Ethan broke up over Valentine's Day. They had been dating for over a year, but Meghan had been starting to doubt whether Ethan was "the one" since Christmas. As she approached her 30th birthday, she no longer wanted to spend time dating guys who weren't serious about commitment. Ethan said he wasn't sure about being a dad. Meghan knew that she wanted to get married and have kids one day. She certainly didn't want to stay in a relationship with a guy who isn't interested in marriage and a family!

On one hand, Meghan was relieved to end the relationship with Ethan. She knew that it was the right thing to do, and it was nice to have more "me time" on the weekends. But after breaking up with Ethan, Meghan found herself staying up late at night checking out guys on Tinder, drinking wine, and feeling sorry for herself. Although she had been keeping up with her medication for bipolar disorder, she found herself drifting into a depression. Soon she was missing days of work and spending most of the day in bed.

Meghan was confused. She wasn't exactly sad about breaking up with Ethan. But, she realized that her schedule was very different now that she was no longer in a relationship. Ethan had been very good for her daily rhythms. Although he wasn't "marriage material," they had often cooked meals together and spent nights together in her apartment watching Netflix. He had a good job in a bank, so he kept very regular hours that also helped to keep her on track.

Losing Ethan meant that Meghan lost important social anchors in her day. Once she realized that her body clock missed Ethan more than her heart did, she put some new activities in her life to take the place of Ethan. She arranged to meet some girlfriends for dinner after work and signed up for an evening yoga class. She also deleted the Tinder app from her phone. As her body clock got back on track, her mood was better.

slides.title: Loneliness, Rhythms, and Moods
slides.body:
Some people have problems establishing or maintaining close relationships. If this results in feelings of loneliness and isolation, it can also cause problems for rhythms and mood.

Chronic loneliness may be a concern for you if you identify with any of the following statements:

  • I have never had any close friends or romantic partners but I wish I did.
  • I have relationships, but none of them are satisfying or fulfilling.
  • My relationships are mostly problematic, characterized by constant fighting and giving each other "the cold shoulder."
  • Most of my relationships take place over the computer or social media. I have trouble when I have to interact face-to-face.

Absence of close, fulfilling relationships can make your mood worse. It may also make it hard for you to use social anchors to set your body clock.

The next exercise will look at how loneliness affects mood and rhythms.

slides.title: Meeting New People
slides.body:
Meeting new people can be hard when you have experienced chronic loneliness or depression. Here are some tips that can help you when you meet a new person.

  • Look them in the eye. At least in Western cultures, eye contact helps improve social connections.
  • Smile. If you are worried about how the conversation will go, your face may show signs of anxiety. A smile is more inviting.
  • Open the conversation with "small talk" (polite conversation about non-controversial topics) such as
    -the weather ("It is so hot outside today, don't you think?")
    -a shared moment ("This check-out line is taking forever, isn't it?")
    -your current environment ("I am surprised that there are so many people here!")
  • Ask questions. Use your curiosity to generate conversation.
    -"What brings you to this meeting?"
    -"Did you like the last presentation?"
  • Avoid one word responses. Try to elaborate when you are responding to the other person.
    -Instead of "Yes" say "Yes, I like this yoga class because it is more intense than the last one I took."

Although meeting new people can be hard, have more social connections will help your mood!

slides.title: The Computer Programmer's Dilemma
slides.body:
David is a computer science major at a large university. He is a top student in the department, always doing well in difficult classes. He has always been good at math and science, and he takes a lot of pleasure in his work.

David, however, has always struggled to make friends. He thought it might be different when he got to college, hoping that he would make friends with other computer science nerds like himself. But, he has been unable to do much more than talk to classmates about homework assignments or, occasionally, join them for an all night hack-at-thon. He knows that a lot of them play video games together, but he prefers to game alone or connected remotely to people that he does not know in real life.

Because there are few people and few anchors in daily routines, David feels like he drifts through life . He sleeps at odd hours and spends most of his waking time on the computer, even eating in front of the screen. It really gets him down.

RAY was great for him because it was easier than talking to a live therapist. He realized he needed to set up a sleeping and eating schedule for himself. That part was relatively easy, because he could create a program for himself with alarms and prompts on his various devices to keep his SRMs in a regular range. His mood lifted as his schedule improved.

However, finding people to help him anchor his routines and provide social contact proved more difficult. When he did the RAY exercise that asked him to practice talking to someone at a party, it occurred to him that he could talk to the guy down the hall about video games. He knew they both played Super Smash Brothers. It was tough, but he was going to see if they could hang out and play together. He felt proud of himself for taking that step. In the long run, he would try to get a regular video game gig going with some other kids in his dorm if this first step worked out.

slides.title: Grief, Rhythms, and Mood
slides.body:
Death of a loved one is an especially difficult experience.

Death is normal, and all of us experience the death of a loved one at some point.

However, death and loss are especially difficult for those left behind.

  • Grief is difficult to bear. It may cause sadness, sleep problems, and difficulty completing tasks .
  • Loss of a close loved one also disrupts rhythms and routines.

If you have recently lost some one close to you, the next exercise will help you examine your feelings about the death and the impact of the death on your mood and rhythms.

slides.title: The Widower
slides.body:
Bob and Jane were married for a long time. Since retirement, they did everything together. They ate breakfast together in the morning. They took long walks together in the afternoon. They watched TV together in the evenings. They even liked to read out loud to each other before going to bed at night.

Jane died last year. Bob misses Jane. His life is not the same without her. He eats breakfast alone. Sometimes he doesn't leave the house because he doesn't have anyone to walk with him. He goes to sleep right after dinner because he doesn't enjoy being in the house alone at night.

Bob's friend Ted also lost his wife to cancer last year. Ted is sad too, but he is more active than Bob. He asked Bob to join his men's walking group. Now Bob goes walking most days with Ted and a bunch of other widowers. That seems to help his mood. He mentioned to Ted that he wished he had something to do in the evenings also, now that he doesn't have Jane to keep him company. Ted suggested that Bob join the poker game at the senior center on Wednesdays. Although he is not a big poker fan, Bob agreed to try it out, realizing that adding some regular activities will help his mood and make it easier for him to bear Jane's absence.

slides.title: Social Rhythm Tip for the Week
slides.body:
Studies have shown that individuals with bipolar disorder are more likely to experience social rhythm disrupting events prior to mood episodes than individuals with depression. Examples of social rhythm disrupting events reported by research participants included:

  • moving to a new residence
  • breaking a limb
  • taking a vacation
  • losing a roommate
  • losing a part-time job resulting in unemployment

This effect is more evident before manic (rather than depressive ) episodes

[insert image from Malkoff-Schwartz paper]

lesson.title: Let's Talk: How Communication Helps your Mood

slides.title: Talking about Communication
slides.body:
Communication is a Two-Way Process

Communication refers to the sharing of information, thoughts, or feelings between two (or more) people.

Effective communication requires

  • A wish, idea, or intent to convey information to another person
  • Clear expression of the information by one person to another
  • Receipt of the information by another person

Communication can fall apart at any stage of this process

slides.title: Communication is Not Just Words
slides.body:
When we communicate face-to-face with another person, we rely on more than just words.

Communication involves:

  • Verbal cues (what we say)
  • Para-verbal cues (how we say it)
  • Non-verbal cues ("body language")

Para-verbal communication includes:

  • Tone of voice (encouraging, warm, hostile, sarcastic)
  • Pitch of voice (loud/demanding, soft/soothing)

Non-verbal communication includes

  • Eye contact
  • Posture (erect and attentive; slumped and bored)
  • Facial expression (smiles, frowns)
  • Hand and arm gestures (pat on the back, folded arms)

slides.title: Body Language
slides.body:
Body Language is a powerful tool in our communication toolbox

Closed body language indicates anger or emotional withdrawal. It is typically characterized by folded arms, avoidance of eye contact and angry facial expressions.

Open body language indicates receptiveness to the conversation or emotional openness. It is typically characterized by good eye contact, sitting forward or leaning toward someone, and interested or encouraging facial expressions.

How does body language change what is communicated in these scenarios?

  • Deirdre says to Roger, "I know it's not your fault," as she reaches a hand out to Roger, pats him on the knee, and smiles sympathetically.
  • Deirdre says to Roger, "I know it's not your fault," as she clenches her fists, scowls, and looks angrily at broken vase next to him.

Sometimes body language is complementary to or consistent with verbal communication. As in the first scenario, it is used for emphasis or to highlight the verbal message.

Sometimes we use body language to communicate that we feel opposite to what we are saying. As in the second scenario, it "undoes" the verbal message, implying that what we are saying is untrue or more complicated than the words themselves suggest.

slides.title: Social Media and Communication
slides.body:
[insert jpg of txt exchange]

Written communication is verbal communication without para-verbal or non-verbal communication. Exchanges via texting or Facebook or email only allow us to convey a small portion of the information that we would usually communicate in face-to-face exchanges.

Emojis, capital letters and emphatic punctuation (!!!; ???!!) can make up for some of the missing para-verbal and non-verbal cues but lack the range and specificity of human voice and body cues.

As a result, electronic written communications work well for factual information ("I will be there at 5 pm") but are less effective for more subtle emotional dialogues.

HINT: Emotionally important discussions may work better when conducted face-to-face.

slides.title: Mood and Communication
slides.body:
Mood Disorders Affect Communication

Many of the common symptoms of depression (sadness, low energy, irritability, anxiety) make it difficult to interact easily with others and interfere with communication. These are examples of how depression affects communication and relationships:

Jordan was so depressed that he could barely get out of bed in the morning. He somehow managed to get to work, but the last thing he wanted to do in the evenings was talk to anyone. He would just shut himself up in his room and let his wife deal with the kids. He didn't even have the energy to talk to his wife about his need for space. Jordan knew that she was angry at him for leaving him alone with the kids, but he simply couldn't put the words together to explain that he needed a break right now.

Mania can also affect communication. Initially (and with hypomania) you may feel that you are on top of the world and able to talk to anyone (and everyone). But, irritability, grandiosity (feeling that you are better than everyone else), and rapid speech usually create trouble with communication and relationships as with Leonora below.

It was 3 am. Leonora pounded on the door of Tia's apartment, demanding to be let in. Tia was confused as much by Leonora's sudden appearance at such a late hour as by Leonora's rapid and somewhat incoherent talk about needing to go over plans to redecorate Tia's living room. Tia tried to suggest that they should discuss it tomorrow, but Leonora became outraged, reminding Tia how lucky she was to have as a friend The Best Interior Designer in Boston and shouting "tomorrow and tomorrow creeps in this pretty pace but your living room won't be very pretty." Tia badly wanted to go to sleep and didn't understand half of what Leonora was saying. She was relieved when Leonora stormed out of the door shouting about the fact that she was doomed to live in squalor.

The cumulative effect of years of manic and depressive episodes may be that you have had trouble learning to communicate as effectively as you would like.

The "flip side" is also true; if you learn to communicate more effectively, you will feel better.

slides.title: Problem Communications
slides.body:
Problem Communication Strategies include:

  • Yelling, shouting, raising your voice
  • Teasing or making fun of the other person
  • Threatening the other person
  • Ignoring the other person's ideas or requests
  • Interrupting a lot
  • Always blaming the other person
  • Talking very little or remaining silent
  • Using put-downs or criticisms
  • Using a sarcastic tone of voice
  • Swearing or cursing
  • Thinking that you know best
  • Walking out or turning your back on the conversation

We all use ineffective communication strategies some of the time. However, if you rely on these problematic communication strategies most of the time, you may want to work on improving your communication patterns.

slides.title: Strategies for Improving Communication
slides.body:
We will discuss 5 strategies for improving communication. Improved communication leads to better relationships which, in turn, will help your mood. Each strategy will be discussed in greater detail in subsequent lessons.

  • Set the stage for communication. Make sure your surroundings are optimal for having the conversation that you hope to have.
  • State your needs clearly. Make sure you know what you want to say so that you can say it clearly to the other person.
  • Make "I" statements. Learn to communicate your feelings more effectively and explain why someone else's behavior makes you feel the way that you do.
  • Be a good listener. Listening is at least as important as talking. Learn to be a better listener.
  • Assert yourself. Learn strategies for being assertive in conversations without being aggressive.

slides.title: Setting the Stage for Successful Communication
slides.body:
Setting the stage for a discussion is almost as important as the discussion itself.

Lay the groundwork for a productive discussion.

Reduce distractions: Turn off the TV, turn down the music, make sure the kids are not underfoot, turn off your phones.

Sit where you can see each other: While it may be tempting to start an important discussion while you are in the car or in different rooms, make sure that you are sitting somewhere where you can easily see and hear each other.

Time of day matters: Think about your body clock. If you are a night owl, trying to have an important conversation at 7 am may be challenging. On the other hand, heated conversations just before bedtime may be too stimulating and may make it hard to fall asleep. Pick a "good" time of day to start the conversation.

Leave enough time for a full discussion: If the in-laws are arriving at 5 pm, it may not be a good idea to start your conversation at 4:30 pm. Make sure you allow an adequate period of time to air all concerns.

Arrange for babysitters: If you have young children, it is impossible to have a thoughtful adult conversation while the kids are awake, and you will probably be too tired to have the conversation after the kids are asleep. If you have something important to discuss, schedule it and make childcare arrangements for the children.

slides.title: What Do You Want to Say?
slides.body:
Know what you want!

Here are some questions to ask yourself BEFORE you start a discussion.

  • What are your goals?
  • What do you want to get out of the discussion?
  • What do you want the other person to understand about your point of view?
  • Do you plan to make a request?
  • What do you hope will be the outcome of the communication?

slides.title: Making "I" Statements
slides.body:
The format of an "I" Statement:

I feel (your emotion) when you (a behavior or condition) because ( describes why the behavior or condition makes you feel this way).

An example of an "I" Statement:

I feel hurt when you come home late without calling because I feel like you don't care about me.

The goals of "I" Statements are to

  • Take responsibility for your feelings ("I feel angry" instead of "you make me angry")
  • Allow you to express a feeling accurately and less hostilely ("I feel angry and hurt" instead of "you make me crazy")
  • Avoid making "all or nothing," over-generalized statements about another person ("I feel mad when you don't help around the house" rather than "You are selfish")
  • Help you be clear with another person about why their behavior is causing a problem ( "I feel frustrated when you don't listen to me because it makes me feel like you think I am stupid or unimportant.")
  • Minimize the other person's defensiveness
  • Avoid blame associated with "you" statements (such as "you are such a jerk!")

In the next exercise, you will practice making "I" Statements

slides.title: Being a Good Listener
slides.body:
To improve communication, become a better listener!

Pay attention
Listen to the person speaking, rather than the "noise" around you.
Look at the speaker directly, making eye contact.

Show the speaker that you are listening
Lean into the conversation with your body to show that you are paying attention. Use open body language.
Nod and use encouraging non-verbal statements like "uh huh" to show that you are listening.

Provide feedback
Reflect what is said back to the speaker by paraphrasing his or her main points.
Ask questions to get clarification.

Practice your listening skills to become a better listener. Like all skills, the more you do it, the more proficient you will become.

slides.title: Asserting Yourself: What is Too Much and What is Too Little?
slides.body:
If you are not assertive enough (common when depressed)

  • You won't make your needs known
  • You won't get your needs met

Examples of non-assertive communication behavior

  • Poor eye contact
  • Soft speech
  • Not asking for what you want or need
  • Always saying "yes" or "ok"

If you are too assertive (common when manic)

  • Others will be frustrated with or angry at you
  • You may hurt or offend others
  • You won't get your needs met because others will be so annoyed or upset

Examples of overly assertive (or aggressive) communication behavior

  • Speaking loudly
  • Frequently interrupting
  • Failure to listen
  • Making demands
  • Talking down to the other person

slides.title: Asserting Yourself: Just Right
slides.body:
Just like Goldilocks found a porridge bowl that was "just right" for her, the goal of effective communication is to be assertive in the "just right" amount.

Assertive communication

  • Respects the feelings and opinions of others
  • Clearly states needs and wants
  • Stands up for your rights

To communicate assertively

  • Make good eye contact
  • Speak firmly and clearly
  • State your needs/wishes clearly and directly
  • Be a good listener
  • Express your feelings but don't be too emotional
  • Practice or rehearse what you want to say

This video summarizes how to be assertive (but not aggressive) when you communicate.

slides.title: Disagreements
slides.body:
Disagreements between two people are part of healthy relationships

However, disagreements can become problematic and contribute to mood symptoms when they are

  • Repetitive (the same argument over and over again)
  • Unresolved (stuck on the problem)
  • Hopeless (it will never work out)

The next few exercises will focus on

  • Identification of problem patterns in relationships that lead to disagreements
  • Impact of disagreements on rhythms
  • Strategies for improving problem relationships

slides.title: Problem Patterns
slides.body:
Disagreements occur when

  • People expect different things from each other

    Josephine liked being in charge. She hired Beth to manage the office, expecting her to handle paperwork and administrative tasks. Beth was very organized and expected that her competence in administrative tasks would be rewarded with greater responsibility. After a year of working together, Josephine acknowledged Beth's skills but refused to give her additional freedom and responsibility. Beth accused Josephine of being a micro-manager. Josephine valued Beth as an employee but felt that she was being arrogant and disrespectful. They both felt angry and misunderstood.

In this scenario, Beth expects Josephine to be "hands off" while Josephine wants to be in control. Josephine expects Beth to be collaborative while Beth wants to be independent. These mis-matched expectations are a set up for a disagreement that, in turn, negatively impacted both women's moods.

Do you have mis-matched expectations in any of your relationships?

slides.title: Common Mistakes
slides.body:
Common communication mistakes that lead to problem disagreements:

Assume that the other person knows what you are thinking: You have just told your wife that you are worried about making ends meet this month. You assume she knows the answer to the question, "Is it ok for me to go shopping for clothes this weekend ?" Never assume! Always say what you are thinking out loud.
Fail to take the other person's perspective: You mother just told you that she is planning to put your father into a nursing home. You cannot believe how cruel she is! You love your father and know that he will be miserable there. You might be less angry at your mother, however, if you put yourself in her shoes. Imagine how difficult it has been for her to live with your father's dementia over the past 5 years.
Give in without sticking up for yourself: You have sex with your boyfriend Zach just to stop him from complaining about the fact that the two of you never have sex anymore. But immediately you feel terrible about yourself for having given in, worse than you did when you weren't having sex. You might be less angry at Zach and less upset with yourself if you had talked with Zach about why you had lost interest in having sex with him and tried to work out some of the issues in the relationship before having sex.

slides.title: Disagreements and Rhythms
slides.body:
People help anchor our rhythms; when we have disagreements, our rhythms can become unstable.
