  • Peter was so angry at Jon that he couldn't fall asleep at night.
  • Cara was so upset by her fight with Julio that she didn't eat lunch or dinner.
  • Tony spent all night pacing, trying to figure out how to apologize to Alicia.
  • Marianne changed all of her contact information to avoid Lorenz. But then none of her other friends could contact her either.
  • Chantal stopped going to work because she was so angry with Brian.

Here are some tips to keep your rhythms stable when you have disagreements

  • Don't have important discussions close to bedtime
  • Don't go to bed angry
  • Remind yourself to eat and exercise, even if you are upset
  • Find positive supports to help you stay anchored when you are in the middle of a fight

slides.title: Improving Problem Relationships
slides.body:
Steps to Improving Problem Relationships

Ask yourself

  • What do I want in this relationship?
  • What are my options?

The first step is the most important. You need to think about "The Big Picture." Wishes/wants may include

  • Improve the relationship
  • End the relationship
  • Get more help from your partner
  • Have a more equal relationship
  • Have a greater emotional connection
  • Experience more physical intimacy

Once you know what you want (Big Picture), generate a list of options which may include

  • Couples counseling
  • Making direct requests for change ("I would be happier in this relationship if we had more intimacy")
  • Bargaining ("if i agree to help more with the cooking, would you be willing to do more child care?")
  • Scheduling time together
  • Accepting that the relationship is ending/over

It is very important that you try to explain as clearly as possible to your partner your Big Picture goals and share your strategies to try to reach those goals.

The next few exercises will discuss approaches to working together to reach your goal.

slides.title: Make a Positive Connection
slides.body:
When you have been fighting with someone, push the "reset" button by making a positive connection. This doesn't mean giving in or giving up. But, sometimes a brief truce will help decrease tensions temporarily, paving the way for making progress in the disagreement.

Strategies for making a positive connection include:

  • Leave a peace offering like flowers or hand-made card
  • Make a meal together
  • Take a walk together and promise not to talk about the conflict
  • Hold hands
  • Tell each other a joke
  • Work on a puzzle together
  • Look into each other's eyes and smile
  • Hug
  • Give and accept a compliment

slides.title: Empathy
slides.body:
Empathy is the ability to understand and share the feelings of others.

Put yourself in the position of the person with whom you disagree. Pretend that you are him/her.

  • How do you feel?
  • What do you want?
  • What do you expect?
  • What do you need?

Taking the perspective of another person--especially a person who you are fighting with--can help you appreciate their dilemma and be sympathetic to their situation.

Carol was furious at her daughter for getting poor grades in school this term. Eleventh grade would determine where her daughter went to college, so she wanted Emma to do well. The more she pushed Emma, however, the worse she seemed to do on tests. Finally, the guidance counselor told Carol that she was being too hard on Emma. She asked Carol to think about the amount of pressure that Emma felt. Emma was applying for several scholarships that required a high GPA, and she was a nervous wreck about it. Carol admitted that her own worries prevented her from thinking about it from Emma's viewpoint. When she really thought about it from Emma's perspective, she realized that Emma wanted to do well and probably also felt terrible about disappointing her mother. When the guidance counselor asked if her if she thought additional pressure would help Emma, Carol admitted that maybe she was making things worse by criticizing Emma's school performance.

slides.title: Positive Requests for Change
slides.body:
What is The Big Picture? What do you want to change?

To make positive, constructive, requests for change, follow these steps:

  1. Look the other person directly in the eye (in Western cultures)
  2. Use a calm tone of voice
  3. Use "I" statements
  4. State your request directly
  5. Be empathic
  6. Tell the person how it will make you feel

Colum and David have been dating for 18 months and living together for 4 months. David has not told his family that he is romantically involved with Colum, leading his parents to think that they are " just roommates." Colum is angry at David for lying about him, feeling that it diminishes their relationship. Colum wants David to tell his parents the truth.

Colum makes a positive request for change using these strategies:

  • "I" statement: I feel hurt when you lie to your parents about who I am in your life because it makes me feel like our relationship is unimportant to you.
  • Direct request: I would really like you to tell your parents the truth about us. I would like you to do this before we go visit them in March.
  • Empathic statement: I know that you are scared, but I will be there for you.
  • Statement of feeling: If you do this for me, I would feel much happier and less worried about our relationship.

slides.title: Rules for Constructive Fighting
slides.body:
When you have an argument (and everyone has arguments), try to follow these rules:

  • Think about The Big Picture. Why are you fighting and what do you want? Are you really angry at your husband for leaving the toilet seat up again or is this about wanting him to help out more with household chores and not dump on you so much? Think about your goal for the fight beyond expressing anger.
  • Take turns talking. Even if you are really angry, take a breath and give the other person a chance to speak.
  • Disagree but don't be disagreeable. Be nice. It will help you reach your goal.
  • No name calling. Swearing, cursing, name-calling and other put-downs make people angrier and don't help resolve the problem.
  • Don't be provocative. Don't say things just to get a rise out of the other person like, "You really don't care about me" or "You make me want to go out and have an affair." Say what you really mean, trying to stick to your feelings and facts.
  • When in doubt, use "I" statements.
  • Be direct. If you have something you need to say, say it. Avoid indirect comments designed to stir up negative emotions like, "You don't want to hear what I have to say" or "Do you want me to say something I will regret?"
  • Focus on the issue. Fights often unravel, moving from a constructive discussion of a problem to yelling and put-downs. Keep the conversation focused on the problem and possible solutions.
  • Take time outs. If things get too "hot," take a time out. If one or both of you gets really upset, give each other some space and come back to the discussion at another time.
  • End on a positive note. Even if it has been a tough battle, try to end with something positive. Thanking the other person for listening or agreeing to disagree can help you both walk away less upset than when you started.

slides.title: All Our Yesterdays
slides.body:
Commonly, those with bipolar disorder look back on their lives and identify a period before the illness started that was different that their current life.

  • Do you remember your life prior to having bipolar disorder?
  • Was your life different then?
  • What was your life like then?

Many miss their old life. Here is what some people have said.

"I used to know how I would feel when I woke up in the morning, but now I am never sure." -Daniel, age 25

"In the past, I didn't have to worry about staying on a regular schedule, but now I have to make sure I am in bed by 11 pm every night." -Tiffany, age 30

"Before my first manic episode, I never worried if I would succeed in life, but now I constantly second guess myself." -Jenna, age 19

What about you? How do you feel about the time before your illness started?

  • Do you miss it?
  • What do you miss about it?
  • Do you ever feel angry about having bipolar disorder?
  • Do you ever wish you could make it go away?

These are normal feelings. It can be helpful to talk about these feelings with someone you trust (a friend, a pastor, your doctor). You can also talk to others who have had similar experiences by connecting with virtual or in-person peer support groups like the Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance

slides.title: Looking Ahead
slides.body:
"I was planning to become a jazz musician when I had my first manic episode. I was playing lots of late night gigs with the band and traveling on the road at least 15 days a month. We drank a lot too. When my doctor explained the importance of regular rhythms for managing bipolar disorder, I realized that making a living as a jazz performer was going to be a problem. Because of my bipolar disorder, I ended up going back to school instead." --Jason, music teacher, age 45

"I always wanted to have many children. During a post-partum depression following the birth of my second child, I was so miserable that, at times, I wished I were dead. It was such an awful experience that I never want to go through that again. My doctor told me that I could be at risk if I went off of my medication to have another child. He told my I could have the option of staying on medication during pregnancy, but that has some risk too. I'm angry that I have to choose between having more children and my mental health." -- Eleanor, mother, age 30

Bipolar disorder sometimes requires you to make changes to or interrupts your plans.

  • Did you have to make changes to your lifestyle or career plans because of your bipolar disorder?
  • Do you feel sad or angry about about effects that bipolar disorder may have on your life in the future?

Anger and sadness about the impact of bipolar disorder on your future is common. Talk to your friends and relatives about these feelings or connect with a peer support group such as Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance

slides.title: Adapting to Tomorrow
slides.body:
"I used to think that I could never be a successful physician because I have bipolar disorder, but I figured out that as long as I picked a sub-specialty that doesn't require me to stay up all night on-call, I can keep a regular schedule and maintain rhythm stability. It wasn't the career path I expected. " --Eliza, radiologist, age 37

"I know that I have to stay on lithium to remain well. However, in order for me to stay on lithium, I had to give up on breastfeeding because it would be too dangerous for my baby." --Cathy, mother, age 28

Many people lead successful lives with bipolar disorder. However, sometimes compromises are needed to optimize health. For instance

  • Taking a job with regular hours
  • Making sure you have health insurance
  • Reducing the stress in your life
  • Asking for help to take care of things that you used to do by yourself
  • Dealing with medication side effects

Have you ever made a compromise to make it possible for you to better manage your life with bipolar disorder?

How did you feel about having to make that compromise? Some people feel sad or angry about having to adjust their goals or plans.

"At first, I was angry about having to make adjustments to my career plans. I wanted to be a surgeon, but that life style was too hard on me. I had worked really hard to get to medical school, and it seemed unfair that just because I had bipolar disorder, I had to change my goals. But now I am working a 9 am to 5 pm job and haven't had a mood episode in a long time. I think it was worth it. " --Eliza, radiologist, age 37

"I was sad that I couldn't breastfeed, but staying well and not breastfeeding seemed a good compromise both for me and my family." --Cathy, mother, age 28

slides.title: Your Path
slides.body:
You can create your own path to success. Make sure that you pay attention to strategies that promote wellness in all areas of your life.

Work

  • Shift work: Avoid jobs that require you to work irregular hours or shifts. This will make it difficult for you to maintain regular rhythms.
  • Night call: Night turn or "on call" shifts disrupt rhythms. Avoid jobs that include these kind of responsibilities.
  • No work: Absence of work or scheduled activities can be just as much of a problem as too many activities. Even if you are not working, make sure you have somewhere to go or be every day.

Social

  • Relationships: Relationships (friendships, romantic relationships, colleagues) help most people's moods. Try to build up your social network so that you have relationships.
  • Social contact: Regular social contact anchors your day. Make sure you have conversations and face-to-face contact with other people every day.
  • Communication: Practice the skills you learned in RAY. Better communication will lead to better relationships which will improve your mood.

Physical

  • Health care: Go to your doctors' appointments and take care of your health maintenance activities like getting regular check ups and doing recommended lab tests.
  • Exercise: Regular exercise is good for your body and social rhythms.
  • Sleep: Get enough (but not too much!) sleep. Stay on a regular sleep/wake schedule.

Stress

  • Plan: Make a "to do" list of all the things you have to do today. Check the 5 most important tasks. Cross off the 5 least important tasks. Put question marks by everything else.
  • Ask for help: When you feel overwhelmed, talk to someone. Ask for help prioritizing or taking care of things.
  • Take time out: Give yourself breaks. Take a 1 minute break at your desk by closing your eyes and thinking of something pleasant. Take a 15 minute break in the middle of the day to take a walk. Take a day off for a "mental health" day.

slides.title: Dealing with Setbacks
slides.body:
Setbacks happen. It is not whether they will happen but when they will happen. More importantly, what can you do do about them?

Here are some tips.

  • -Don't panic: Some mood fluctuation is part of the natural course of bipolar disorder. You may be having a bad day. Give yourself some space to relax and use skills taught in RAY. It may just pass with time.
  • - Recovery is often an up and down process: Getting better is not a straight line. Most people who get better have good and bad days on the road to recovery. Rather than expecting that every day will be better than the last, it is more reasonable to check to see if there is improvement week to week or month to month. Use your SRMs to keep track.
  • - Ask other people for help: Getting help from others does not take away from all that you have accomplished. It shows that you have learned to take advantage of your social support network. Ask for help when you feel worse.
  • - Remember that it's not your fault: Worsening mood may indicate that this self-help approach is not strong enough or that you need more help than RAY can provide. Talk to your doctor about other treatment options.

slides.title: Talking to Family and Friends
slides.body:
Talking to family and friends about bipolar disorder can be challenging. If you haven't had "the conversation" with them yet, here are some suggestions that may help.

  • Have information available. You should have information about bipolar disorder easily accessible to give them. It is helpful to let them read about bipolar disorder from an expert source. The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) is a good source of information. Click here for more information about bipolar disorder from NIMH.
  • Write it down, Before you start, write down the main points that you want to make. It will help you stay focused and organized.
  • Leave enough time. Don't do this when you or they are rushed. Leave time for discussion and questions. And for the sake of your social rhythms, don't do it late at night.
  • If you get a bad reaction, don't freak out. This information can be hard to process. Remember that the other person's reaction is more about them than you. Give them time and space to think. You can revisit the issue later after they've calmed down.
  • Line up support for yourself. If you expect that the conversation will be difficult, invite a support person to join you or set a date for coffee afterward so that you have support during and afterward.

The more people who understand your struggles, the bigger your social support network.

slides.title: Reviewing Progress
slides.body:
As RAY comes to an end next week, it is important to think about what you have accomplished over the past 11 weeks.

  • Have you met your SRM goals?
  • Has meeting your goals had an impact on your mood?
  • What effect has RAY had on your relationships?

Maybe some goals were harder to achieve than others. For those goals, consider these possibilities:

  • Is this something that you are still working on, that you might still achieve with more time?
  • Would you have had an easier time reaching the goal if you broke it into smaller, more manageable pieces?
  • Is the goal no longer relevant?
  • Did you learn something else while trying to meet the goal?

slides.title: Controlling My Fate: What are the Early warning Signs of Mania?
slides.body:
Warning signs are changes in mood or behavior that signal that a person may be about to have a manic or depressive episode. Warning signs are unique to every person.

Common warning signs for mania include:

  • Talking faster and louder
  • Invading other people’s personal space
  • Needing less sleep
  • Feeling more anxious
  • Making impulsive decisions
  • Starting lots of new activities

Warning signs can be hard to notice:

  • Symptoms are often mild and don’t cause major problems in everyday life.
  • You may not know your warning signs for mania yet. Sometimes you have to experience a few episodes before you can figure out what your warning signs are.
  • Friends and family members sometimes notice changes before you do.

If you catch mania early, sometimes you can prevent it from developing into a full-blown episode.

  • Preventing the consequences of a manic episode helps you stay on track in your life.

  • If you have had episodes that have resulted in negative consequences such as hospitalization, disrupted relationships, or job problems, it is especially important to spot the warning signs as early as possible.

slides.title: What are the Early Warning Signs of Depression?
slides.body:
Common warning signs of a depressive episode include:

  • Feeling slowed down/fatigued
  • Being more self-critical
  • Feeling hopeless
  • Lower self-esteem
  • Loss of interest in things you usually like
  • Withdrawing from people you normally talk to on a regular basis

You don’t have to feel sad to be at risk for starting a depressive episode!

  • It is common for ”depression” to feel like numbness or emptiness.
  • Sometimes you won't feel sad but rather feel sluggish or slow.

Sometimes it can be hard to know the difference between warning signs of depression vs. mania. For example, increased irritability and anxiety could be a warning sign for mania in one person, and a warning sign for depression in another person. Warning signs that are common for mania AND depression include:

  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety
  • Poor concentration
  • Irritability

slides.title: My Early Warning Signs
slides.body: [Interactive tool here]

slides.title: Getting Help: Relapse Prevention Planning
slides.body:
The time period between the first symptoms and "full blown" mania or depression is different for every person. It can last anywhere from a day to several weeks.

Knowing your warning signs will allow you to seek help for an episode before it takes over your life.

Sometimes your loved ones will notice these warning signs before you do. It is important to enlist friends and family members in relapse planning whenever possible.

Planning for relapse means creating a plan to stop your episodes before they get out of control. Relapse prevention plans are created when you are feeling well and consist of a written list of:

  1. Your warning signs
  2. What you will do when you notice you warning signs
  3. What your loved ones should do when they notice your warning signs

slides.title: Rhythms and Relapse Prevention
slides.body:
**

Life changes and rhythm disruptions can trigger mood episode.

**

Think about whether your mood may be especially vulnerable to specific life changes that upset your rhythms. Think back to what was going on in your life just before the start of depressive and manic episodes in your life. What kind of changes happened before you mood shifted?

  • Did you have increased stress at work?
  • Did you have to stay up all night to finish a project?
  • Were you arguing with your spouse?
  • Did a certain life event cause you to have decreased contact with friends and family?

Identify life events that altered your rhythms and induced an episode in the past. Can you think of an example?

You may need to be especially careful when faced with a similar event in the future. Add to your relapse prevention plan a strategy for paying extra attention to any change in your mood or behavior when faced with these kind of life or rhythm changes.

For instance, if you developed your first manic episode after an especially difficult exam period in college, you may very vulnerable to sleep deprivation and stress. You may wish to add to your relapse prevention plan a statement like the following:

"If I get less than 6 hours of sleep, I will take it easy the next day, calling off work or not going to class if necessary. If I have two days in a row of less than 6 hours of sleep, I will call my parents to let them know that I may be slipping into mania again."

slides.title: My Doctor and Relapse Prevention
slides.body:
It is important to maintain a healthy and trusting relationship with your doctor. So, work with your doctor to create a unique plan outlining what to do when experiencing abnormal mood changes or having an episode.

Some things to consider when creating a plan with your doctor:

  • What number(s) should you call or who should you contact when you are starting to notice warning signs? (Family? Friends? A hotline?)
  • What number(s) should you call for an emergency? (Hospitals, mental health clinics, crisis numbers)

When talking to your doctor, make sure you tell him or her the whole story!

  • Let your doctor know if you have not been sticking to a regular routine, getting enough sleep, or engaging in risky activities
  • Be honest about any missed medication doses!

Your doctor cannot make the best decision as to how to help you unless he or she has all the correct information!

When in doubt or if you experience thoughts of suicide, go to the nearest emergency room or call 911 for help.

slides.title: My Family/Friends and Relapse Prevention
slides.body:
Keeping close family and friends involved in helping to monitor your illness can help you stay healthy.

  • Tell them or give them a list of your warning signs
  • Provide them with information about bipolar disorder
  • Ask them about what warning signs they notice in you
  • Come up with a plan together for what to do when one of you notices the warning signs
    • How do you want them to approach you when they notice these warning signs?
    • What do they want you to do when they approach you? How do they want you to respond to their concerns?
    • What should they do if you don’t listen?
    • Are they allowed to call a doctor or hospital for you?

slides.body: [Interactive tool here]

slides.title: Keeping the Beat!
slides.body:
You’re on the path to success! After completing RAY, you have new skills that can help you take control of your life and your illness.

Remembering these important points will help you and your rhythms:

  • Your body clock is affected by cues in your environment. Keep those cues as regular as possible.

  • Your mood is affected by--and affects--your body clock.

  • Keeping a regular schedule helps you stay on track and prevents future episodes!

  • Stay on track with good sleep habits. Try to go to bed and get up at the same time every day---even weekends!

  • Monitor your SRMs to detect changes in your mood and rhythms.

  • Work on communication. Good communication improves relationships which helps your mood.

  • Keep others involved ! Educating close family/friends about your illness will have a positive impact on your health.

  • Know your warning signs! Keep a list of your possible warning signs and look at it periodically to remind yourself. The more you know your warning signs, the better you will be at detecting them when they show up in your life.

Keep the beat!
